750 ml bottle.  Popped the cork and the beer went nutz.  Wonder how long it was waiting to do that.  Huge head and very foamy.  Aromas were sweet with bright fruits.  Flavor was yeasty at first, some alcohol and breadiness in the middle and slightly bitter, dry finish.  Pepper on the finish too.  Not bad.  Just not my favorite style.

From an original Magnum bottle, at the brewery - the REAL thing  Orange-gold, good yellow, dense & fine head, stable, fed by good pearling. Very peppery-spicey, citrussy nose: sweet sugar candi, and a sour touch. Sweet, young malt taste, with a retronasal flavour bouquet of honey and spices (curaçao, coriander,...). High attenuation, first gristslickness and quite some alcohol!! Lot of restsweetness apparent in the aftertaste. Way better than the Du Bocq versions. Sample quite young, but alrady in fine shape.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2006 Pours hazy orange with large head that dissipates slowly.  After letting the bottle warm closer to room temperature, it gives off a nice floral and spicy aroma.  The taste is similar - complex floral and spicy taste that is dry and light, but not sweet like some tripels.  Yeasty finish.  Relatively high abv is not noticed.  An excellent tripel that you should try!

Cloudy yellow gold hue, with a splendid rocky white head, leaving nice laces, the nose is one of an apple fruitiness, yeasty, anise spiciness, and a slight floral hops in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a good yeasty character, spicy herbs note, hint of apples and pears fruitiness, with an alcoholic warming accent, leading towards a dry floral hops finish.

(Bottle) Hazy orange beer with a thick, lasting head.  Pleasing aroma that is sweet and spicy with yeast and some citrus. Some bitterness with bready and sweet taste.  Not overly complex, though.  A good flavor, but it could have been more.

This 750ml bottle was my wifes Valentines Day gift to me, and I drank it tonight in her wonderful company. I love you, hon! OK enough mushy stuff. Pours a slightly hazy orange-gold color, with a big, creamy white head. Mediocre lacing. Nose is great - a touch yeasty, a bit of orange, light malt, some spice, and an overall fruityness. Medium body. Lightly fruity flavor, perfect balance of fruit and spice. Finish is spicy, just a hint of bitter, and light fruit. Really feel this is underrated!

[ Bottled ; chilled ; B/B 11/11/06 ]
A fully lasting small rocky white head that tops up a hazy medium yellow body. Moderate lacing. No particules. Bottle conditioned. Aroma presents malt as moderate hay while hops are heavy lemon / lime and grass. Yeast is minty and citrusy. Also, there are evident traces of coriander and mint/pepper. Initial flavor is moderate acidic/citric while development is moderate bitter. Finish is long and bitter. medium body... oily texture... Fizzy carbonation... Yet another excellent triple.
Aroma is yeasty. Nice colour. Malty and hoppy taste. Hints of various fruits and spices.

Slightly hazy, dull yellow body with a large white head. Fairly good head retention and lacing all the way down the glass. Yeast stands out in the aroma along with a little orange and alcohol. Fortunately the taste is not too sweet, some spice notes, medium body with the alcohol well balanced and easily drinkable for me but not for the missus.

Rates high in my book all the way around. It pours a light orange color with a head that looks like something out of a washing machine. Yeasty aroma in the nose with a pepper hint that is unmistakable. So far, so good. The taste isnt very sweet like some Triple can be. Instead, its peppery and complex that makes it more intriguing. Very warming and very good. Great belgium beer.

Picked this up at Flame Liqours on US-1/PGA in West Palm Beach.They have started selling singles and their selection is one of the best Ive seen. ever. Duvel shaped bottle, but poured into a tripel styled glass. Poured golden honey, clean, and crisp. Nose is wash of citric-yeasty with a bit of pepper. Taste is yeasty grassy notes, malts, mild hops and some clove spice, though represented much different than a darker brew. Very smooth drink and the alchohol is well hidden. A solid belgian.

Medium gold, pretty head.  Fruity (apricot) aroma with definite hay and yeast notes.  Flavor is a dead on match, with the addition of a woodsy note that blends nicely with they hay.  Good mouthfeel.  A very nice, well made tripel.
Bottle - 75 cl. Light orange - dark yellow. Large creamy head - medium duration. Nice combination of sweet and bitter. Very fruity.

(bottle - 11.2 oz) Hazy orange color with a creamy and soapy white head. Yeasty and peppery aroma with lots of sweetness in it as well. The taste begins with a slightly watery, yeasty flavor with a sweet and peppery middle and a warming and sweet alcohol finish. Medium-bodied, yet slightly warming.

This sample is from a 750ml bottle although I have enjoyed it immensely from a larger than life bottle (9L or so).  It pours a light orange with a fluffy white head and lacing. Sweet, spicy, yeasty, and malty. Great complex spicy and yeasty flavor that came through more fully in the larger bottle.  Overall a very well made beer. Ill take a giant  bottle anytime.

Light colored beer with a big fluffy white head. Now this is an amazing beer. I especially like the fact that is not too sweet, which is a problem i have with a lot of belgian beers. Very happy with this one.

Very estery fruity aroma,with something that smelled like a hint of mint(?) pale gold pour with the usual big Belgian head, fruity malty taste with a definite overtone of candy sugar,a little carbonic bite on the tongue, barely taste the alcohol for a tripel . Cant remember the last time I had a Belgium brew that wasnt great

750ml bottle at Tapwerks, OKC, OK. Shared with Jzzbassman and mjames. Poured a glassful of white head. Yeasty aroma with mild fruit notes and spice. A little apple and a little banana. Lightly sweet and mildly spicy. A nice beer.
One of the better Tripels Ive had in awhile. Floral aroma with hints of candied fruit and spice. Flavor was melon and pepper, with a nice finish without being too sweet.

Wow, the big old 96 in the Bayesian % has psyched me up for this one.  The pour is muddy golden with 1-finger off-white head.  The aroma is very floral, flowery, with some spicy nectar hints, sort of like smelling a peony.  There is also strong peppery and some funky and candi sugar notes.  The taste is extremely black peppery/spicy/floral, with hopcitric notes and some honeydew and honey hints.  Tons of different aromas and flavors in this one.  The palate is very complex and very lively.  It gets fruitier and spicier as it warms, like a quarter honeydew dolloped with honey and ground black pepper and showered with parsley.  This one is a real gem, and you should get some today, and get some for your mother, too.
12oz BottleClear light golden with a big white head. Spicy aroma some pepper, smooth body with a crisp finish. Lightly sweet flavor, a bit of metallic in finish. Overall an average Tripel
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Slightly murky golden white appearance.  Floral, pungently sweet nose full of tulips, coriander, light honey and spicy yeast scents.  Crisp and even on the palate, not too dry, moderately spicy flavor with some prickly sweet fruit and honey flavors.

Pours clooudy yellow with overwhelming head which continues to rise from the bottle.  Nose is citrusy with lightly hop/spicyness. Palate is fruity with seemingly increased carbonation on tongue.  Mild yeasty finish.

super murky yellow with a thick head that left thick webbing.aroma and taste were of lemons,fruits,and sweet malts.as is sat the carbonation died down as well.i thought this helped smooth the beer out a bit.very nice triple indeed.

Light color -- sort of yellow, orange, cloudy look to it.  The head was explosive!  Only poured a little and it was coming out.  Very tart, subtle fruit flavors.  Some yeast, lemon peel flavors.  More bitter than sweet, but still a good amount of sugar, cookie flavors.  Nice.

Bottle 0,75 L. Fantastic appearence and aroma. Excellent fully lasting head, nice yellow colour. Heavy hoppy aroma, loads of citrus. Powerfull taste and long finish. Very dry texture and soft carbonated. YThis is what beer is abour.
Deep golden colour. White head. Fruity sweet aroma with yeast. Rich flavour dominated by malty sweetness. Great mouthfeel.

750 ml bottle, St-Feuillien glass. Pours a rather cloudy golden color with a very thick frothy white head. Sublime aroma of spices, citrus and yeast. Excellent flavor of citrus, spices and yeast. The body has a light to medium thickness with a dry,powedery texture and low carbonation. An excellent, robust tripel.
Bottle. Spicy, wheaty aroma. Golden colour, stable white head. Looks flat. Flavour starts off dry, and turns a little more malty. OK bitterness.
Another great tripel. Big light head, nice bouquet, nice color. Tastes good too.

Purchased in Jan 04. This Triple uncorked easily but took several tries to pour. Some went on the floor too. The carbonation is out of control. Now that things have settled down. This beer looks very appealing. Golden apple juice color with a white head. Smells like a Belgian ale. Yeasty and a bit fruity. The beer has a spicy finish partly due to the excessive carbonation I think. I taste apples, pears and aluminum. Pleasant fruity aftertaste. Something faintly metallic bites my tongue on every drink. Im not sure if I like it or not. Still, all in all a good beer.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2005 From a bottle this beer pours a bubbly gold with with a fair head. Yeast on the nose with a touch of veggie sweetness. A hoppy spiciness on the tongue with a longer bitter quality than the average tripel. Lively carbonation in the mouth and smooth going down to the belly. Another above average belgian.

Pours a very light golden color bordering on yellow.  small head with lots of lacing.  The aroma is sweet and fruity.  The flavor is bitter (kind of a funk like taste) with a slight hint of sweetness at the end to add to the warming flavor of the beer.

330cl bottle.  A golden slightly hazy beer with a huge white head on pouring but this clears faster than expected.  The aroma is peppery, lemony and yeasty.  It is quite subdued and inviting.  The taste is also clean and uncomplicated with typical spicy yeasty tripel characteristics.  Very drinkable, seems to go out of its way to be so.
Bottle poured a golden yellow with A frothy white head. Aromas of apple cookie and celery. Flavors of cookie, pineapple, pepper and a bit of grapefruit.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy gold with a big head and high carbonation yet is very smooth.  Aroma is spicy, yeasty with some leather and pepper.  Flavor is light pils malt with a touch of earthy hops and a good amount of spice kick.  Very smooth overall and easy drinking.

75 cl Bottle. Yeast in bottom. Golden colour with a white fine foam. Aroma of yeast and some sweetness. Smooth taste with hints of some sweetness and spice .Fine bitterness in the aftertaste, midium to big body.

750 ml bottle, corked champagne-style. Bought in Denmark. Large white head. Beer is clear (hazy when I poured the sediment in) pale golden. Very nice yeasty aroma with notes of fruits, spices, horse stable and some oak. Flavour is initially sweet, spicy and yeasty with decent hops. Light bodied for an 8.5% ABV beer, alcohol is well hidden. Aftertaste is dry with a hoppy and spicy bitterness. A decent triple this one.
A highly flavored beer with medium longlasting head. Golden colour, bitter medium body. Very strong beer.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2010 A nice looking and tasty beer. Very light, but the alcohol is noticeable. I let my girlfriend rate this but I have to say she gave it just about the same score as me. Girls who drink beer are awesome.

Interesting golden hazy body with little particles in it. I found an inviting spicy aroma which reminded me of westmalle. The first sip reveiled a refreshing mix of flavors including honey, light coriander (or herbs?), spices and yeast. This tripel reminded me of the Fin du Monde from Unibroue but perhaps a bit more subtle and refined.

330lm bottle from Open All Hours, Keswick. Very good stuff, and better than I remember from our previous encounter in Brugge. Hazy orangey yellow. Rocky persistent head. Aroma of fruit, complex yeast (>1 strain?), spice, curacao. Hint of sweetness in the taste, finish sweet, hoppy and complex.
pour golden/orange with a fat white head, very smooth tasting with a little bite upfront, smooth like silk on the way down. great  sweet taste, i loved this beer, very drinkable.

Bottle - 330ml. Superb golden/orange hazy body topped with a thin but lasting white frothy head. Aroma is surprisingly dominated by hops and herbs. Various hints of honey, spices and yeast. Alcohol remains well hidden. Taste is well balanced but is less complex than the aroma is. It is quite dry and it leaves a long bittersweet aftertaste. This very nice Tripel is a babystep below Chimay or Achel.

750ml bottle: Mostly clear golden yelllow with a large, frothy white head.  Aroma is grass, slightly tart pears, with a hint of banana, a touch of lemon, and a bit of esters.  Flavor is a mixture of light citrus, grass, and grain up front, followed by some light fruits, some yeast, spice, alcohol showing through, light malts, and a bit of pepper.  Finishes dry with notes of light wood, grains, a bit of grassy hops, and a slight alcohol burn in the nose.  Light to medium bodied, slick mouthfeel, moderate to high carbonation.

Slightly hazy golden color with a nice big white foam head on top.  Aroma is mostly grassy notes, not very sweet or citrus smelling.  Flavor has a slight sugary taste to it, but its mostly a robust malt and medium citrus taste to it.  Palate is rather dry, pretty good beer, but far from amazing.

Poured slightly hazy gold in colour, with a persistant white head. Aroma of pepper and spice, with some fruity esters and alcohol. Flavour is very fruity, lots of esters and spice. Alcohol does show more than I expected. Not a bad tripel though.

A Mes rate:
Oh how I wish I could have this on tap. Just about as good as tripels get in my opinion. Just like the regular St. Feuillien but with nobs on and oh what nobs they are! Downable and does the trick every time. Great stuff. Anyone who enjoys beer will love this.
Very light and sweet in spite of the alcohol. Fruity scent, large white lasting head. Pours straw yellow and goes down easily with a fresh and dry taste.

Sampled at a festival. Poured a light gold color with an aroma of pears and cinnamon. The mouthfeel is thick and full. The taste is dry apple cider with some black pepper spice in the finish. A little on the dry side for a tripel.
Nice mix of spice, fruitiness, Tripel strength and a touch of bitterness.  Great aroma and great texture...

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2005 (Bottle 75 cl) Well, I guess this is what I usually refer to as Pilsener-golden, but slightly hazy. Gigantic head which is also very sturdy. Quite full, soft and sweet with a lovely malty flavor that makes me think of grains. My friend Anne Holst thinks it deserves a straight 4, but Im a bit more modest.... 110603

Bottle. Golden beer with a big white head. Aroma of sweet malt, cotton candy, yeast, spice, some fruit. Citrus and summer fruit with yeast and malt coming together to give it some richness and depth. Dry and not sickly sweet like many poor attempts at triples. This one is nice.

Golden coloured, and seemed quite carbonated.  This one wasnt too bad.  Maybe I was expecting something else from this ale, thus I think my drinking was a bit biased with this one.  It was a tasty beverage, but I think it was a little too light for what I like.  I absolutely love the head on this one, the bubbles lace is kind of mesmerizing!  My buddy really enjoyed this one, more than I did, if that means anything.

Bottle, at home.
Golden, nice and longlasting white head. Not filtered. Sweet aroma of malt. First sweet flavor, next light bitter. The strenght is felt.

Dated 26/08/04 on bottle. Hazy golden ale with a creamy white head.Light sweet aroma with bnotes of corianrer and  alcohol. Sweet vanilla fuge caramel with nice  hops bitterness and alcohol warmth finish with a  an oily mouthfeel.  Pleasant drinking while cooking! MMMM....

Bottle: Poured a light golden color ale with a medium head with about average retention. Aroma is kind of sweet with something floral also included in the mix. Taste is very enjoyable with some wheat mixed with spices that are well balance with an nice floral undertone all the way through the end. Overall, a very fine Abbey Triple but maybe still a notch down from Westmalle in my humble opinion.

75cl bottle, 131484 on cork.  Wonderous gold color w/ all kinds of bubbles floating, great lace, head a little lacking.  orange, lemon, fruity nose, vanilla, malt...Very elegant sweet/spicy beer.  body is perfect, not heavy at all, but vibrant and sexy.  Finish fades into spice mud with hop accents.  Solid beer, drinks like a feather: easy.  SPicing is apparent, but mysterious and not overdone.  Im impressed.

Pours an amber color with copious co2 and a full, rocky, white head.  Aroma is fruity, fresh and lightly grassy with a malt background.  Flavor is sweet at the start with a yeasty bite at the finish. A metallic flavor lingers when it is colder, but dwindles as it warms. Palate is lively with plenty of co2, medium bodied, lightly creamy, yet crisp.  Looks like a tripel, smells like a tripel, tastes like a tripel   I enjoyed this beer, yet did not fall in love as I was expecting.  It has the right idea, but does not pull off the complexity or the balance of a great tripel.

Pours golden orange with a tight head. Simple light citrus aroma, with dusty pleasant yeast on the palate.  Hint of florals, citrus in aftertaste as well.  A good, slightly above average bottle-conditioned triple.  Would try again.

Pale and golden with an unimpressive white head. Nice floral, spicy aroma with some candi sugar and mineral smell. Spritzy and dry for a Tripel. Good body and a bit of finishing bitterness. Some herbal flavors. Recommended. In general I prefer a Tripel that has a creamier and less sharp quality to it, though.

A slightly hazy Orange tinted beer with a light beige head. Corriander & bubblegum with a lemon twist. Sweet & fruity with a slight spice flavor, a hoppy herbalicious follow. Very good but a bit fizzy. Similar to the Moinette Blonde I just had.

75 cl corked bottle; hazy orange color with good head aroma is wonderfully sweet and acidic, and kicks you in the head like a huge back of fresh fruit jelly
taste is unusually bitter (for a belgian ale) with a little bit of unpleasant sharp/salty bitterness,  some hints of licorice (saaz?) Champagne like carbonation

Poured from a 9 Liter bottle into a tulip glass. The beer was a nice yellowed orange color with a good 2 fingers of head that fell to coat the beer. The nose was my favorite part of this beer. Banana, peppery spice, pineapple. Divine. The flavor was a nice creamy banana spiked with lemon and pepper. Very nice. The feel was a bit creamy and moderate. Drinkability was also good. Smooth and very refreshing beer. I look forward to my next graduation. I will be getting a 9L of this to celebrate!

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2004   I like this beer.  However there is a bit too much of an orange juice taste in this beer.  I dont mind it.  There is just too much of it.  The bitterness and the aroma were very nice.  Ill have to try this in one of the big bottles with the cork.  Beers are usually much better that way.
(750ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy golden body with a large rocky long-lasting white head.  Aroma of earth, fruits and mustiness.  Flavor of yeast and spices.

Bottle from CaptainCougar.  On opening the carbonation rushed to escape.  After waiting abaout a minute the pour suprisingly isnt all head.  Hazy orangish color.  White head, modest lacing.  Very fruity and yeasty in aroma, some hints of spice also.  Very well carbonated, dances on the palate.  Medium bodied.  Peppery tingles, fruit and yeast in flavor.  A pretty tasty triple.

Here we go again.  Spent good bucks to have this sent from one of those on-line distributors.  Just had to try it.  Determined to find Belgians I like.  Well, this wasnt one.  Cloudy orange with a full beige head.  Aroma was sweet and spicy but unappealing.  Full-bodied and slightly astringent.  The flavor had too much going on for me to enjoy and decipher.  Apologies for the negative review.  Then again, some of my favorite stouts have received them from people.  To each his own.

Sampled out of a 3.0 L bottle. Dark Yellow.  Strong, musty, yeasty aroma of clove, banana, tangerine and spices (possibly cinnamon but Im probably wrong).  Very well balanced.  A strong and strange orange zest in present on the palate, along with a touch of bubble gum, ripe fruits, apples and coriander.  A nice interpretation and overall, an enjoyable brew.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2007 Bottle @ Belgian Beer Fest 11/04.  Knew I had to try this one, as Ive read all the good reviews and wanted to see for myself.  Pours a rather pale yellow, with light golds.  Small amount of haziness, with some deeper bright gold hues.  Small white head.  Aroma seems pretty straightforward, light citrus, almonds, light spicing and hopping.  Little yeast and alcohol presence.  Flavor is very unique.  Ah, so this is what sets this one apart.  Its like a trippel with tons of unusual spicing.  The spice erupts right away on the palate and then fades leaving you with a good yeasty, lightly malted trippel.  The palate being sufficiently dried out from the spice, the yeast is quite noticeable and the light honey-almond malt only sneaks in a bit.  Very unusual.  Perhaps a bit too much astringency.  I would like a bit more malt to back up the hops and spices.

Sparkling golden body topped by a very large frothy white head. Very lively bubbles. The aroma is mildy sweet with some dishwater and perfume. Perfumed dishwater??? The flavor is mildy sweet, somewhat malty and fairly bitter. The dishwater shows up again. Medium assertive body. Sweet and bitter finish that lasts when it might be better if it went away. Not well balanced.

Gotta admitt, im rating this beer while im drunk! But I I sure like this beer right now! Fresh arorma with hint off hops. Flavor is mild but powerfull at the same time! This is a good beer for gettin drunk!

Yellow/gold color, with a rather large, white head. Aromas include hops, a little fruit, and flowers. Flavor is also flowery, with some malt. Ends is a little bitter. Palate id just right. Not top of the heap, but pretty good.

Golden and opalescent, with a white foamy head of long persistence, compact and adherent. Very hoppy aroma with hits of wild flowers. Flavour is sweet and spicy, medium bodied with a dry hoppy finish.

Shiny clear gold.  Head big and puffy, but fades rather quickly.  Nose perfumed and flowery, bit sweet.  Flavor starts spicy and peppery, blends to some melon fruitiness, quite dry at the end, rather yeasty.
Golden color, Heavy yeasty spicy aroma and sweet taste, medium body, Light sweet spicy finish.
Bottle bought up in Belgium. As pale as Fosters Lager. However this isnt carried through into the aroma or taste, as its full of flavour, spicy and hoppy, yeasty and peppery. Excellent Tripel

Bottle. Harsh lemon and yeast in the aroma, slight hint of it being stale. The palate was softer than the nost was suggesting. In many ways a typical triple, yeasty, peppery, appley(and also pears), with some lemony acidity, slightly dusty, spicy mouthfeel, with a little alcohol in the finish, reasonably bitter, felt a bit stale though, yet it was within the use-by date, didnt like it as much as their others.

Stubby 330 ml Duvellike bottle. Light golden with huge white head. Strong lacing. Powerful aroma of fruit, nectar rich flowers, green apple peel, fresh rising yeast.  Intense and quite complex flavour: fruity, especially  grapefruit, a bit sour but also sweet and bitter, goodly touch of ripe melon.
Lively carbonation- watch for those beer burps! Alcohol (not too shabby at 8.5 %) nicely tucked away. An absolutely delightful triple. Positively a threat to my sobriety.
Nice Belgian Triple. Huge white head and a very lively mouthfeel. Good stuff!

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2004 Very powerful flower-hoppy, peppery-yeasty aroma even at a cold temperature. Interesting "conventional" light golden color - from a distance could pass for a light pale ale. Thick head with lacing so strong the lip marks actually stay on the glass! Flavor somewhat bland but with some intense fruity gushes, and a sweet-and-sour complexity going down. Like so many excellent Belgians the afterglow is the highlight of the brew - intensely bitter with grapefruit and slight raisin tinges ... and needless to say enough intense beerburp carbonation to cure even the worst indigestion. [Slight revision 09/11/2004: subtracted 1 point in Overall because the yeast element is slightly overprominent in the carbonation.]

Clear golden hue, and a towering, fantastic, huge white head. Aroma is gorgeous and spicy, with citrus and honey notes. So far, its a perfect profile for a tripel without even taking a taste.
And, that taste? Divine! Utterly lovely, light, buouyant, with a dazzling hop prominence at first, and a good touch of graininess in the texture. Sweet, light, and scrumptious, and the sugar starts to take prominence here in the middle.
An utterly unreproachable tripel, and a complete delight. Top-notch tripel, beautiful beer.

A hazy orange beer with a huge beige head. The aroma is sweet spicy with notes of coriander, gooseberries, yeast, and citrus. The flavor is very sweet, but not too much, since it is combined with loads of different spices; coriander, orangepeel, yeast, earth, and wood. In the background lies a acidity - that balances the sweetness perfectly.

Bottle pours pale golden, slightly hazy, large fluffy white head, fairly sticky lacing, with tremendous amounts of carbonation.   Sweet spices on the nose, slightly fruity.   Spices, earth, some citrus, and pepper on the tongue.   Good body and mouthfeel.   Finish is long, earth, spices... Mmmmm, the 8.5% isn't even detectable.   A good, soft, tasty Abbey Tripel.

Poured golden yellow with long lasting thick white head...smells of spice and lemon...malty at first, then yeasty and bitter...finishes sour...on a little different note, I have never had this much trouble uncorking a bottle.  I absolutely could not uncork it.  It wouldnt twist, pull, pop, anything...I took a knife to it and carved a notch around the mouth of the bottle and it FINALLY popped...I am almost done with the bottle right now and my hand is still red and hurts...all in all, this was NOT worth the wait...a decent beer though...

white head with larger bubbles, then gets really rocky.  cloudy golden body.  candi sugar, honey, lemon peel nose.  floral aroma.  grapefruit nose.  super fizzy mouthfeel start.  a little watery then nice, gentle hop nip.  alcohol well hidden.  bready finish, light peppery finish too.  some funky lacing arcs on the side of the glass.  my favorite XXX blond!

Hazy amber/golden color with a large rocky white head. Aroma of bread, spice
and citrus. Yeasty/malty flavor with spices(coriander,cloves,pepper) and a 
moderate hop bitterness.
Fruity yeast aroma of quality. Nice and moderate lace. Some fruit in the sip. A bit complex in spice with cloves . Tad of sediment Spicey bit astringent lemoney finish and aftertaste.

Pours with a thick, fluffy head, not much lacing (dirty glass?); aroma is citric and yeasty, notes of apple and pear; it has a peppery, spicey, clove flavor overlayed on a sweet malt base, finishes somewhat dry; overall, a tad too spicy, for me, good balance......not bad

EYES: Dark peach cloudiness with nice lacing. NOSE: Yeast, light alcohol, flowers and clover honey. TONGUE: Nice bubbles, soft flavor with numbing alcohol and a buttery pear essence. The yeast are that of a country ale, you know, humble yet rich and inviting. Clean, tranquil, inviting palate. IMAGINATION: A very family farm/agrarian beer. I envision this as a nice lunch beer after having hand cut and sheaved a 10 acre field of hay. Then sitting at an antique table under a low spreading european oak with fine cheeses and a basket of fresh eggs in a straw ladden basket. Drab colors, flagstone and ivy. Never has a label so captured a beverage.

Normally I prefer tripels that are dominated by sweet fruit instead of spice, but this was very nice even though it fit in the latter category.  Poured cloudy light orange with a medium off-white head, emanating a complex, perfumey and spicy aroma with pepper, bread/crackers, pineapple and flower petals.  Flavor presented apple peel, grassy hops, cracker and pepper, perfume, coriander and white grape.  Very rich.  This is quite a nice tripel.

07.07.04  750ml bottle.   Classic tripel on the pour, beautiful golden orange; massive head; sporadic lace.  Aromas are big and fruity; cobweb and earth aromas are more than subtle, I also smell fresh greens (dandelion or arugula) and cracked pepper, maybe some citrus.  The front is fast, a big malt punch yields to surprising and pleasing hops dry flavors and body.  Hints of fennel in the beers crisp middle.  Wonderfully effervescent throughout.  Outstanding example of one of my favorite styles.

Honey colored with a moderate white head, slightly hazy.  Aroma is floral, peppery, sweet(Light Belgium candi sugar) and yeasty.  Flavor is well hopped for a triple, with a slight amount of tartness.  Bubbly mouthfeel, balanced finish, excellent beer!

I must have had a bad bottle, becuase it had very off phenolic notes. Band-aid like sourness with a acetyl twang.  Will have to get another bottle to try.  Bone dry with a rank aroma. smelled like rotted lemons.  It was not at all pleasant and like any triple I have had.  Cork nearly blew a hole in the ceiling

Clean golden hue with large fluffy head and very good lace. The aroma as hints of barnyard and dusty yeast esters, aromatic hops, bready malts, orange zest, lemongrass, coriander(?), simple sugar, and some phenol. The taste has notes of apricot, apple, orange zest, spice, wheat bread and sublime bitterness, complex but not overpowering. The finish is subdued spice, honeycomb, yeast, and light alcohol bite. This is a very well made brew and almost a summertime tripel, recommended.

Big bubble white head which settles nicely.  Nice aroma of white grapes, yeast and wheat.  Maybe a touch of spice.  Color of apple juice.  Flavor  has a nice alcohol kick.  Clean, crisp and smooth.  Light fruit, some malt.  Not much hops presence.  Expected more in a triple.  Finish is warming from the alcohol and clean.  Again not muchs hops presence.  A very delicious and refreshing brew that is great for the summer even with the hops missing.

I had been aging this beer for about 9 months until now. 
Rating # 470  Cork Reads Lot N: 130343
Ive got the proper St. Feuilliens glass and everything for this beauty. Pours with a most lively Golden straw colored body and a snowy caped head.. appears as a goddess!
 The aroma is slightly barnyard.. musty notes of wheat, apricots, cleanly milled grains, and a doughy yeastiness thats making me salivate! Damn, ohhhhhh damn! The flavor is superb! A sweet note of honeysuckle, creaping jasmine, and blooming spring gardenias, its so flowery and alluring! Yeasty and buttery like a warm doughy biscuit, but with a notes of almonds and peaches. SO very fruity..... a truck load of ripe melons jackknifed on a county road and  resulted in this marvelous Triple!  

 Amazingly Delicious!

Normally i do not like tripel so much, mainly because ive had some boring ones like Leffes. The only tripels i like is this one and Tripel Karmeliet. This one pours hazy dark yello, nice white head. Spicy and yeasty aroma. The flavor is also very spicy. I really liked this one.

Again I must say that triples are really not my thing! This one pours a hazy dark yellow body with a foamy white head. Aroma is heavy and spicy. Notes of hay, cheese, pepper and alcohol.  Flavor also has plenty of spices along with hay and alcohol notes. Very dry and a little sour. This is a typical triple!
An excellent beer. Nutty and slightly sweet the high acl volume is not noticable. Great scent clear redish color and really smooth drink make this a favorite. Try It

Medium dark golden pour with a thin, bubbly, lively head. Thin lacing. Sweet aroma of baking bread, cotton candy, corn-syrup laced fruit cocktail, bubblegum, and just a wee bit of alcohol. Sweet enticing flavor,  with hints of light maple syrup, pears, and candied sugar. A bit of sweet spiciness adds a nice touch. Lively carbonation, perhaps a tad too much. Finishes strong with the alcohol hidden quite nicely, thank you.
UPDATED: MAY 21, 2004 Lost my notes.  Will have to add lots of good commentary later.

Pours cloudy gold with a nice head.  Aroma is yeasty and fruity.  Flavor is fruity, nice malt with a very nice bitter spicy finish to balance.  Mouthfeel is carbonated and lively.  Alcohol present but not overbearing.  A nice tripel.

Medium gold w/a  lasting white frothy head.  Strong spicy hop, yeasty, and woody cork aroma.  Light malt sweetness with very little fruitiness.  Very dry flavor...grainy malt, hop bitterness, well balanced, spicy and yeasty; lightly bready with a hop flavor in the finish and aftertaste.  Lighter bodied but highly carbonated, warming alcohol with a dry mouthfeel.  Very good tripel IMHO, could use some aging to smooth out the bitterness since I like my tripels on the malty side, but quite enjoyable.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2009 (Bottled, 0.75l) Hazy golden with large, firm head. Clean aroma with plenty of sweetish, grainy maltiness, only a touch of acidity, and lots of pear fruitiness. Flavor is very fruity, very slightly acidic and alcoholic, with a nice, grainy malt base. Quite full body and fresh palate with low carbonation. Some cellary aroma is brought in with yeast, so I guess this will improve with ageing. Even when fresh, a really nice and balanced summer tripel.

Nice bright yellow color with a fluffy white head leaving a nice Belgian  lace on the glass.  Fruity aromas balanced with spicy hop character.  Very light bodied and crisp in flavor.  Clean finish.  I could drink this beer all the time.

Bottled: Light yellow coloured. Dusty. No head at all. Sweet, malty, yeasty, spicy and flowery aroma. Light alcahol, malt some spices in the flavour. Full and wellbalanced beer. Has a nice aftertaste. Sharp but still balanced.

Very pale and hazy golden yellow. Toasty, almost pilsner-esque aroma. Exceptionally dry with delicate notes of banana, pear, and clove. Soft mouthfeel with gently effervescent carbonation. A refined and refreshing triple.

Pours a clear gold color, and it is topped by a thick white head.  Aromas of yeast, alcohol, ginger, apricot, pepper, and dust waft from my glass.  This is a pretty good tasting Triple.  Lightly sweet with a tongue prickling carbonation.  Fruity notes of pear and apple can be found here.  This beer finishes with a lightly astringent bite.  The taste has notes of pepper, grass, and something I can only describe as a lightly dusted old room type thing.  This beer has a certain softness to it that reminds me of vanilla at times.  This beer is a bit like flower nectar as well.
Rather highly carbonated and a big head. Fruity, strong aroma, and a taste that matches. A very good triple. Those guys at St. Feullien knows how to brew...

750: Crisp golden color with a nice white head and lots of carbonation (gusher!). The aroma is spicy with some banana and orange along with the nice smooth pilsner malt background. The flavor is also well rounded, a little to be desired, but still rich and filling along with a zesty/tart mouthfeel. The tail is short and spicy. Good triple, I like.

Textbook tripel. Slightly hazy golden. Small beaded fluffy head. Bittersweet aroma with mild yeast. Notes of grass. Flavour has some great hops and chewy buttery malts. Stinging pepper. Lightly floral (rosey). Clean with a honey and butterscotch finish. Boozier as it warms.
Pale color with a nice lasting head. Very fruity. Smooth tasting. Malty rich beer. There are some notes of hops in the finish. Well balanced. Well made beer.

Cloudy yellow with a big white frothy head. Aroma is citryssy, yeasty, grassy, malty. Candi sugar noted as well. Malty rich beer with candi sugar hints and some dried fruit flavors. A little hops in the finish. Well balanced.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 17, 2004 (Pizza Port Belgian Beer Party in Carlsbad, CA) Spicy flavor, but not over the top; Sweet like a standard tripel, with a somewhat sticky mouth feel; Mildly bitter; Pale golden/yellow color and very cloudy; Fairly white head doesn't last long

This triple pours with a yellow body topped by a thick head with lots of lacing.  The aroma is sweet, citrusy (lemon) and yeasty wtih some spiciness and a touch of tropical fruit.  The flavor is slightly sweet yet bitter and spicy with a touch of dark fruit.  Full bodied, dry and slightly warming.

cloudy orangish-yellow and bright with a solid sheeted head..yeasty, straw-like aroma with honeycomb and tangerines.  straw-like flavors, subtle citrus notes, yeasty, clean, and down right refreshing.
Aroma and flavor have mandarin, curacao, some licorice and honey. Lovely aroma! Sweet and not massively hopped, but has enough character to make it a good beer.
Very cloudy with light hints of orange and spices.  A light and effervescent start with notes of pepper. A thick mouthfeel and light notes of freshly cut grass.  An outstanding beer!

Great big yeasty and mal aroma.  Light / pale orange in color.  Huge white head that is very clingy.  Taste is like a real tripel, not some sugared up wannabe.  Very sharp flavor of malts and some notes of banana.  Very Good.
Small and very smooth head. aroma is fruity with some spices. Flavor is sweet which hides the high alcohol content. Palate is very nice.

Pours light flaxen with a small white head and spotty lacing. Very nice aromas. Spices, tart fruits, and some specialty malts. Flavors consist of banana, clove, and more of the tartiness that was in the nose. Nice body, palate was fairly tart, and ends with a nice mix of spice and bitterness.

Bottle. This beer formed a large sized white head that was rockey with fine-medium sized bubbles that were long lasting. The body was transparent with fast rising carbonation and a yellow-gold hue. The nose was light hops, citrus, sweet, spicy and fruity. The flavor was sweet and spicy and the mouthfeel was tingly and fairly smooth. This beer's lacing was decent.

This bottled brew poured a very large head of foamy fine to medium sized long lasting white colored bubbles that left behind a fair lacing.  The body is a transparent carbonated light yellow color and the aroma is floral yeasty and has a note of coriander to it.  The mouth feel is tingly and initially smooth then finishes with a mild hop bite.  The flavor is interesting crisp and has notes of malt  mild fruityness coriander yeast and dough.

11.2 oz bottle.  Fiercely roiling tiny bubbles in a champagne sea, snowcapped with nevermelting foam.  Honey, wildflowers, and yeasty dough pummel the nose, but tiny hints of butterscotch soften the blows.  Complex sweet and sour notes soar in harmony together on the tongue, light acids and smoke tingle the throat, the end lasts as long as the beginning.  Beguiling and distinct, classy and illuminating.

Bottle pours a nice golden color with a decent head and very nice lace.  The aroma is yeasty, with a bit of pineapple.  The flavor is spicy, fairly hopped, fairly sweet, and somewhat dry in the finish with a medium rich palate with a cleansing carbonation.  Overall, I like the way the spice flavor works in this one.

Bottle Conditioned. BBE Dec 2004.  Yellow with white head - not very interesting. Gentle spice aroma - fairly pleasant. Carbonation a little too lively for my taste, giving a slightly hard edge to an otherwise fairly smooth palate. Alcohol is smooth, only making a warming presence in the finish and on the swallow. Soft spicy flavours typical of a triple. Slight lingering hops and yeast leaving a pleasant bitterness in the mouth. Not a knock out beer, but certainly more than acceptable.

750 ml. brown Belgian bottle. Corked and caged. Lot number 130343. No freshness date seen. A loud "POP" releases the cork from the bottle, and also the genie within. Poured out a deep straw yellow, with a huge white, meringue-like head. It stuck around until the bottom of the glass, leaving a ridiculous lacing and a thick matting on top of the beer.
Aromas are of fresh cut hay, Belgian yeast, slight alcohols, lactic wheat tang, pineapples, fresh fruit, and slight hops notes as well.
Tastes are of fruits of every description, strong maltiness noted as well. The flavors dance on your tongue, tempting you to try just a little more. Thanks, I will.
Mouthfeel is rich and creamy, in part due to the high level of carbonation. Thick texture, slightly chewy even. Almost a meal in a glass.
Dangerously drinkable. Alcohol is well hidden, but warming upon impact in the stomach. I put away an entire 750 ml. bottle in one sitting, and I sat. And sat. And sat some more.
Great beer overall. Well worth the effort to seek it out.
Had an overly caramel character for a triple... heavy mouthfeel, abundant alcohol, much like a Bock rather than a triple

Pale golden color, surprisingly light haze, moderate head formation. Great earthy, spicy, woody aroma with hints of banana. Sweet fruity palate at first, some banana and pineapple juice. A hop dryness balances while the second half has a mild bitter bite and plenty of spice.
Dark amber. Big lasting head. A strong beer, with a lot of sweetness. Has a "soapy" impression
Very light perfume and bubblegum aroma.  Soft and supple malt, well-structured with nice mouthfeel. Good yeast spice late.  Elegant and beautiful.

hazy orangy gold, big hite head.  honey, pepper, and spice aroma with some bicuity malt and a hint of earth.  more honey and some vanilla notes in the malt, but not too sweet.  peppery yeasty spice  leading to a mlidly herbal(grass, dill?) finish.  overall very smooth and expertly balanced.  excellent.
Hazy golden color with a white head. Lightly sour floral and vegetable aroma. Bubblegum, floral and salty vegetable flavors. Very tingly feel with a dry finish.

Slightly cloudy golden color with a white head. The aroma was very floral, with some mustiness, and bubblegum. The flavor was slightly bitter with some outdoorsy character and a bitter hops bite in the finish. The feel was very gassy...chapagne-like with a dry finish.

750ml into delirium tremens snifter: Hazy blonde hue, perhaps a little too clear. Dense white foam with quality lacing. Aroma of banana, very fieldish feel, light spicing and yeast character and pleasant flowers. Good malt presence in mouth, malty hay if that exists, just tart enough to mention it with notes of citrus (lemon) and apple. Overall very smooth body if a little biting. Complex, Delicious!

Clear golden with a white head. Yeasty, sweet nose, tiny hints of phenol. Spicy, quite sweet with honey and some phenolic notes, a bit orangey as well. Overly carbonated, but leaves a nice, dry finish.
(750ml bottle) Thin, white head and an amber body. Strong lemon nose. Lightly carbonated. Floral, smooth vanilla, citrus and spice. Excellent!
Golden color, a bit of haze, white head. Aroma was yeasty and spicy, tiny bit of hops. Flavor was fruity, yeasty and kind of spicy. Fairly light body. Pretty good.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2016 Banana, pear and bubblegum esters stretch onto herbal hops which grow within this Tripels crisp honeyed maltiness...A bouquet of hay and flowers floats atop doughy yeast and alcohol warmth...Striving to do better is always appreciated...

BTW, a 3 year-old bottle proves to be as complex, lively and flavorful as a fresh one...

750ml bottle.Yeasty mildly hoppy fruity pear aroma.Sparkling blond appearance with fluffy full head.Dryish hoppy flavor combined with fruity pear apricot flavors.Mild sweet long balanced fruity and hoppy aftertaste.Very good Belgian tripel.

11.2 oz bottle.  Very slightly cloudy golden yellow with a huge frothy white head that is mostly diminishing.  Aroma of bananas, spice, yeast, lemon, some malt and pepper.  Light palate but it fills the mouth with lots of carbonation.  Nice complex flavor of bananas, lemon, apple, pear, cinammon, pepper and yeast.  Not quite as sweet as I expected, more of a dry champagne flavor. A very good beer.
Clear golden body lies beneath a large white head. Aroma is bready and yeasty with some fruitiness. Taste is yeasty with a slight fruit character, spicy hop flavors in the finish. Excellent Triple.
Clear golden coloured, nice head. Spicy citrus aroma. Fruity, floral and a bit spicy flavour. Nice finish! Good beer.

#600 Weak nose of citrus, flowers and incense (i hope i spell this word correct). Quite clear yellow coloured with some particles. Taste is floral, bit yeasty and fruity-sweet. A very pleasant smooth palate. The palate is what makes this beer so good.

(11.2oz bottle)Slighly cloudy, bright yellow with the classic, big, fluffy, lacy triple head. Nose of exquisite pale malts, some lemon, corriander and hints of yeast. Medium bodied, watery texture, big, tasty, fresh pale malts, subtle sweetness and spices. Lemony hops, dry yeast character and a bit of alcoholic warmth and taste. A good triple but not as good as I thought it would be. Will try bigger bottle next time.
Bottle 750ml.  Light golden color with a fine white head.  The aroma has a dry yeasty champagne and apply character.  A complex spice bursts into the palate with a sweet candy finish.

Ah, the glories of Bob (former boss & good friend). Hard to beat getting the glass and having it filled from bottle that comes up to about my waist (9L?) But of course that was only by way of introduction to a classic tripel. Deliscious stuff. have long thought that there's often QUITE a difference in small bottles vs large and I'll have to see if the smaller ones come in if that idea holds with this. Smooth, complex. fruity, slightly dry - oh, what to say? I like it. That I do.

Large head, golden body. Aroma; sweet, fruit (peaches, citrus), yeast and spice. Fruity and yeasty taste with some pepper (complex). Theres been some difference between the 33cL and the 75cL bottles I´ve had - I prefer the smaller ones (less yeasty, less peppery).
Nice yellow color with a very nice white head, that lasts a while. The taste is spices, fruits, yeast and oranges or lemon. Nice triple.
Great triple.  Spicy, fruity, and yeasty flavor.  Finishes clean and dry.  Recommended.

Bright golden yellow, fluffy head that settles down into a patchwork of tight bubbled foam. . . Light peppery yeast aroma full of lemon zest, pineapple, and fresh flowers that tickle the nose and excite the mind.  Very spicey mouthfeel, light orangy alcohol, pears and all manor of flavourful spices mix with bubble gum and cotton candy.  A fabulous tripel.
fruity and spicy aroma, well measured bitterness (yeasty) and sweetness (just enough)

Golden colour with orange highlights and a very large pale white head. Small bubbles rise from the bottom, just as any good belgie should. Smells of yeast, bread and the freshness of a few coriander seeds come out very nicely. Medium bodied mouthful with plentiful carbonation. Yeastie taste complexed by the tangyness of grapefruit and citrus. The palate is very drying and leaves you waiting to take that next sip. With all said, this is a pretty good tripel, definately better than the last tripel I had: La Fin Du Monde. Worth trying, especially if you can find it! I bought this 11.2 ounce bottle at Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York.
Pale golden body, medium white head, fruit and spice in the nose. Zing of spice with a refreshing body, not overly sweet. Complex and with more subtlety than most tripels: a winner.
Yeast, bread, citrus, golden/amber, small solid white head. Bready, grapefruit flavour, bit of lemon too, some humbug candy at the conclusion? Full bodied, complex, a very good example!

Nice golden colored pour with a big, creamy white head that lingers. It has a spicy, peppery aroma of hops with a nice malty sweetness and a good fruity and yeasty profile in the background. It has a medium body with lively carbonation and a crisp mouthfeel. The flavor up front is malty sweet with some spiciness. The finish is spicy and peppery with a bit of hops and a semi-dryness that is quite refreshing. The alcohol is well hidden. Excellent beer.
Hazy blond color; rocky generous head. Dry spicy aroma. Dry taste, malty, good but Duvel is much more…
What a good beer! From the pour came that light blonde cloudy color with a whipped cream head. Full of spice and body. Nice lingering finish.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2006 Rerate, aged 3 years 750ml bottle: Pours a clear deep golden bronze with a very nice, frothy, dense lacing white head.  Aroma of sweet sugary Belgian malt, lots of light fruitiness and some bready yeast.  Body doesnt seem too different from what I remember.  Its a little drier perhaps, with some more floral character.  Seems to have aged well.

Original rating 7/1/03 12oz bottle: Sweet malty, bready, Belgian yeast aroma wafts above the golden blond body.  A big, lightly-lacing, rocky white head lays atop.  Smooth sweet maltiness fades into a semi-dry, oaky finish.  Palate is smooth with a carbonation that turns into an airy, soft and full body. Light pleasant complexity hides the alcohol very well.  One of the best tripels Ive had.

Had this at the Bon Vivant Beer Lovers Club on 6-27-03. This was the best of the evening! Blond with a hint of brown intruding it's way through the light. Cloudier when the sediment is added. Nice thick, rich whitish head. Smell of flowers, fruit and yeast with a little of the 8.5% coming through. The taste made it for me. More apple and pear with spice, like cinnamon or nutmeg. Creamy, bubbly body and a smooth long dry finish made this a pleasure to consume. Great beer!

Crystal clear yellow brew. Ridiculously huge, white, rocky head. Incredible lacing.
The aroma is of clove, banana, apricot, RAID insect spray and alcohol.
The flavor is malty and sweet up ront with notes of apricot nectar, banana and warm alcohol. Decently balanced with an atringent and lightly pungent hop presence on the backside.
Medium-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Short, slightly sweet, slightly dry finish with spice and corn at the far, ok, short end. Very nice, "almost" world class trippel. Thanks go out to CaptainCougar for this fine brew!

Pours a light hay color with a decently thick, frothy white head.  The aroma is both hoppy and sweet.  Bitter citrus, sour apples, spicy and sweet.  Pleasantly soft and creamy in the mouth.  A nice bitterness in the finish to compliment the candi sugar, strong spices and a touch of well-hidden alcohol.  Quite tasty and very well done.

Classic Belgian head and lace. Very carbonated. Nose of fresh ginger and orange zest. The palate is very sweet and fruity with a healthy dose of candi sugar and coriander. Long finish that is peppery.
A beautiful golden color with champagne type bubbles rising through the glass.  Lovely tasting with perfect carbonation.  Sweet flavor.  Excellent finish.  Awesome.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2003 Update:  How did I forget to note the creamy palate?  Amazing.

Old:  What a great spicy flavor with restained coriander.  Hugely bright, lively carbonation.  Perfect balance--no element is overdone.  This is my favorite tripel.  Elegant.
Effervesce is the word for this beer. Yeast and fruit in the flavor. Still refreshing. Very well-balanced. One of the best triples available.
From the moment you open and pour this beer the experience begins. I have to say it is by far the best beer in flavor and presentation I have experienced yet.
A very classic Tripel. Golden. Fruity, spicy and yeasty with pineapple notes.

Looks really nice - golden body, and a thick, lush, bubbly head.  Smooth finish, a tiny bit tart, yet a hint of sweetness.  Smells very spicy, and it tastes exactly like it smells - spicy and a tad of fruitiness.

Clear golden - compact frothy head - spicy, yeasty aroma - the flavor up front is spicy, peppery, tart - that makes way for a mild, sweet fruitiness and a subtle malt presence - lingering malt on the tongue, slight alcohol - a pretty good tripel.

Some overflow after opening the corked 750mL. Big, fluffy white head with a typical belgian aroma, some floral notes. Flavor is typical belgian (I'm always at a loss as to how to describe this other than belgian-like). Slightly sweet, candi sugar definitely present, moderate amount of malt thrown in as well. Overall a decent triple, but nothing that really impressed me.

Wow has a very nice pale yellow color to it. Has a lot of citrus flavour to it, definitely can taste the different hops on this brew. Head stays strong throughout the whole drink. A very well done triple.

A very nice pale yellow color with a thick white head that would not go away. This beer had an excellent aroma of clove and hops. Flavor was more of the same with an excellent dry, fruity finish. A very good brew.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2006 A truely impossible cork to remove without a corkscrew.  Pours a golden clear color with a large creamy lasting white head.  Heavy yeast, straw( not fresh but straw that has been in the hayloft awhile and pitchforked around), pears, and alcohol.  Slightly sweet with fruits and ginger.  Testure is syrupy and creamy.  Finish is slightly bitter.

This beer poured a golden color and formed a huge foamy head that coated the glass with lace as it subsided. A good deal of carbonation is present. An aroma of malt, hops, citrus and spices. A flavor of malt, hops and spice. A warm feel of alcohol is also present, but not overpowering. Somewhat of a buttery finish.

Lot No. 020506.  A slightly hazed golden liquid crowned with a off white tall big bubbled head.  Aroma of exotic fruits steeped in a light cloves spice and a touch of licorice.  Lively fresh fruit with a hint of earthy yeast start the flavors.  Further sips reveal more fruit, but mingled with mint and herbs.  Hints of dry hops and lasting hops oils on the tongue in the finish. I have found one of my top triples.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2007 750 ml:   Clear pineapple liquid.  Typical Belgian rockiness with solid lacework.  Lovely balanced sweetish/fruity aroma with bountiful esters and subtle mustiness.  Soft notes of slightly burnt rich sugar, ginger, dough, jelly, flowers, oranges, leather, grass, light perfume, apple, and a trace of pale malt funk.  One of the best palates I have ever experienced:  Expansive bubbles upon first sip, which quickly convert into a mind boggling creaminess.  Exquisite blended flower and tangerine flavors.  Lots of additonal depth in the subtle grass, lemon, and rock candy notes.  Slight medicinal, melon, and mint notes.  Coarse hop edge.  Lingering soft rose and round peach shades.  Appetizingly clean and dry toward the finish.  Light musty belches.    Amazingly complex and balanced in both aroma and flavor department.  Each sip is more delighful than the last.  It cant get much classier than this.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours cloudy hazy dark yellow in color, has a huge white foamy head of small bubbles lasting head. Fruity and spicy flowery aromas. Fruity buttery and spicy yeasty flavors. Somewhat sticky but dry finish. Full bodied with lively carbonation full but crisp, clean mouthfeel, alcohol is hardly noticed, a really enjoyable tripple.

Poured with a nice fluffy long lasting head that gently settled down into little islands of puff bubbles.  This one seemed very finnicky about serving temp - when it was just a touch too cold, it was harsh and sharp; when it warmed just a few degrees more, the alcohol really started to come into the mix.  However, while it was at that perfect temp, it had a great light tartness and a mellow sweetness - like summer fruits.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2007 750mL bottle. Head is initially large, frothy, white, mostly lasting. Body is hazy dark yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted bread/grain), lightly to moderately yeasty (cobwebs, basement), lightly to moderately hoppy (herbs, flowers), with notes of clove and lemon zest, light notes of Juicy Fruit gum and alcohol. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Lean and clean, and always seems to satisfy. Its not big and bold, but rather takes an elegant, understated approach to the style. Its frighteningly drinkable and properly dry. Consistently delightful.
Nose of honeydew, bubblegum, big head. Smooth and clean with a spicy kick at the finish.
The colour is golden, very opaque with a beautiful head. It has a superb aroma of butter and spinach. The flavour is quite acid, citrusy and peachy. Long but too acid aftertaste. Fresh and excellent.
Blond beer with a huge slightly creamy head. Light flowery hoppy aroma. Slightly sweet, spicy, liquoricy,hoppy taste.Slightly bitter finish and aftertaste.

Hazy orange color. Huge frothy head with clingy lace work. The nose is hoppy, spicy, dirty, with floral aromas shining through. Feels spritzy on the tongue. Warm alcohol finish from your throat all the way to your gut. Odd aftertaste.
Hard to find in NJ, but worth looking for... malty, great color and flavor.  First had at a bar in Le Roeulx near the bewery.

I agree pretty much with the commercial description. The problem I had was that the lingering taste seemed a bit metallic to me.  Perhaps it was an abnormal bottle.  I may re-rate as I have a few more at home..

Caramelized honey-pot gold under a feather white pillow, medium lasting head. Fresh green fruit, honey, warm doughy malt, light spices, hop bitter and faint wine cellar yeast aroma. Some scotch ale character with medium sweet soft alcoholic start and less bitter palate. Lowly carbonated luscious smooth texture. Ear warming alcohol takes some 3 mouthfuls to kick in. Sweet but not sticky delicate fruity desert wine alcoholic finish. I  imagine this would be an excellent cold weather beer,
Light spicy aroma, strong white head and not as spicy in flavour as some triples, but thats a good thing
It had a very different smell but one I really liked.  The taste was a bit sweet.  It was a beer that I really enjoyed

Cloudy yellow orange in color, large and frothy white head and sheets of lace. Nose is earthy, slight bubble gum tones, malt, the front is lightly sweet, the top is light, the finish is highly carbonated, quite astrigent, dry, hop bitter, and the 8.5 percent abv is apparent in the finish and the bottom of your tummy.
Hoppy,spicy,alive with zest.

Pleasant, mildly bitter-sweet flavor with a strangely sweet-ish finish (though not unpleasant).  Different from anything Ive had before.  It was what I think of as a Belgian (sweet, yeasty, rich), but with a bitterness that was unfamiliar.  As it warmed, it developed a bit more of a bubble gum flavor and aroma.
Very big head with golden unfiltered body.  Bubblegum aroma.  Sweet & complex flavor, with mild astringency at aftertaste.
Large frothy head with citric undertones in both the aroma and flavour.  A good accompaniment for moules and frites.  It is definately an incentive to sample more triples.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2003 Sweet and somewhat vinous, citrus aroma. Pours with a mostly diminishing fluffy white head.  Spicy and hoppy taste when cold (40 degrees F). As beer warms the bitterness diminishes somewhat, greatly improving the overall experience.  Slightly sweet, candi sugar flavors.  Light body with a refreshing effect on the palate. Long spicy finish.   NOTE: I HAVE SEVERAL 750ml BOTTLES FOR TRADE IF INTERESTED.

The hoppiest triple Ive yet had. Piney, citrusy aroma and taste. The aroma also had substantial yeast and malt components, and was spectacular. Long spicy finish. The commercial description This beer has a white, smooth and very compact head is right on!

text: Delicious tripel. Firm head. Golden color. Spicy aroma and flavor. Resisting palate.
This is the kind of triple I like. Lively, complex, and not overly sweet. A true classic!
It has a beautiful head and a nice lace, the colour is cloudy blond. The aroma is fresh, pleasant and floral. It is complex, spicy, slightly tart, well-balanced. It has a long spicy aftertaste.

Snow-white foam of fading consistancy over a limpid golden brew with lazy flight of bubbles looking like inverse snowfall.
Lively fruity and hoppy aroma, alas without ultimate complexity nor distinction.
Foams well in the mouth, refreshing, and leaving a dry hoppy taste, without particular intensity.  Long and slightly dry and bitter aftertaste.
Another quality beer from this excellent producer, in spite of which the penultimate Trappists are not quite reached.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2005 light hazy blond colour, fine and firm head, apple and bready aroma, notes of honey, sweet and full-bodied, light bitterness, bready and fruity finish (orange zest) with some reidual sweetness - a beauty
These beers deserve alot more credit than they get.  Another great beer.
